subject: Re: [junit] Don't show exception messages to users (was assertTrue(true))

messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Kevin Lawrence wrote:
>>"Social security number should match the pattern 999-99-9999. AB-1234-XY
>>is not a valid social security number."
>
> You're still thinking like a programmer. "Match the pattern
> 999-99-9999". What's that? "Match the pattern" is programmer speak. It's
> a perfectly good exception message for a programmer; but you need to use
> different language when talking to a user. Something like, "AB-1234-XY
> is an invalid social security number. Social security numbers contain
> exactly nine digits, and no letters. Please check the number and try
> again." Furthermore, you might vary the bit about "exactly nine digits,
> and no letters" depending on exactly what they typed. If they typed
> eight digits and no letters, you could say, "Social security numbers
> contain exactly nine digits. 987-6543-2 only has eight."

Agreed.

The important pieces of information here are:
* It's an invalid Social Security Number
* The number that was being looked at as AB-1234-XY.

The exception needs to propagate this information out. That's it.
Formatting this into a usable and understandable error message is the job
of a reporting layer. Sure, a default message may be present, but that's
not the important thing.

These things can and should be tested. So, the test would look like this:

public void testInvalidSSN() {
try {
new SocialSecurityNumber("AB-1234-XY");
} catch (InvalidSocialSecurityNumber expected) {
assertEquals("AB-1234-XY", expected.getBadNumber());
}
}

Don't like lots of typed exceptions? Then use a general one. As long as
those two bits of information are there, you can construct a meaningful
error message - at any level.

Please note that rethrowing a ParseException certainly doesn't count as
good... :)
